div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m., a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR SERVICE.
div.p: With the object of bringing up-to-date the British Consular Service, an organisation, known as the British Exporters' Association, has recently been formed, with the Duke of Abe room as president, and a number of distinguished members of the Colonial Service and eminent business men as an advisory council.

The association, which makes its appearance under such favourable auspices, has set itself the task of supplying the fullest information and special reports as to the requirements of any market manufacturers wish to enter, particulars of the competition to be met with in different countries, the classes of goods sold, prices, import duties, shipping routes, freight rates, etc. Then, in addition, the association will supply the names of the leading buyers and merchants in any country, obtain catalogues, and, if necessary, samples of foreign competitors' goods, furnish reliable reports as to the status of any buyer, information in advance regarding anticipated contracts of foreign governments and cities, and translate for members correspondence from or into any language, free of charge. These are but some of the facilities for increasing British trade that manufacturers who ' are members of the association will enjoy.

"We have had 20,000 inquiries of all sorts in one year," said the hon. secretary. "They all tend to show bow enormously, with tact, enterprise, and energy, our export trade may be increased. What the association wants to do is to stimulate and protect the export trade of the country. We hope to develop into a selling organisation for British manufacturers in the sense that we shall introduce the buyer and the seller. Then our duty will cease. For three years I have been working at and organising the association and for that purpose I have made inquiries of 7,000 persons of all classes in all parts of the world. We have our agents and representatives now in every city and centre of importance throughout the world, and with that all completed we are getting on to our legs at home, and want the manufacturers and merchants to join ns and reap the advantages of what has been done in the interests of our own country and its export trade. We already have 200 members, but we have scarcely appealed yet. We are doing that now." "You are of opinion there is still plenty of room for expanding British trade V "Unquestionably. All our inquiries and the reports of our agente go to show that. But the British manufacturer must get abreast of the times and adopt the methods of his competitors. He must, for instance, quote his price free at the port of delivery, and not free on board in London ; he must quote it in the currency and the weights and measures of the country he is dealing with ; he must accept a more enlightened method of payment, and other things. We are prepared to do all this for him if he will only allow us. There is nothing about this association of a political character," said Mr. Bryant in conclusion. "It is all for trade and nothing but trade."

In an interview the secretary (Mr. Bryant) said he had received letters from all parts of the world, showing how much the association is already appreciated by English and native firms abroad. There was one from Smyrna, welcoming the association, and pointing out the antiquated methods of English houses as compared with German in Eastern trade ; another from Naples, saying there was a great demand for British goods if the manufacturers would only study the wants and customs of Italy ; still a third from Bombay, sending specifications and asking for an estimate for a mill, complete ; and a fourth from Valparaiso requesting tenders for a small railway. These were but specimens selected at random.

div.head: Killed by a Scorpion.
div.p: A native child of Sboobra was stung by a scorpion on Sunday and expired shortly afterwards.

div.head: Raid on Cambling Den.
div.p: A gambling den was successfully raided on Sunday night in the Mohamed Aly street, Cairo.

div.head: Protection of Kasr-el-Doubara.
div.p: It has been decided to mount an officers' gnard at Kasr el Doubara, which will famish a sentry at General's Honse. Lancashire Fusiliers The date of the departure from Cairo of the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers is still uutixed, and nothing has yet been settled as to their embarkation.

div.head: Native Tribunal.
div.p: During the month of Ramadan, the native courts will be open from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., and the olerks and Mohz:m offices from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m.

div.head: Express Nile Steamer Co
div.p: The first tourist boat of the Express Nile Steamer Company will be launched at the Bahr el Aama arsenal, near Kasr el Nil bridge, tomorrow afternoon.

div.head: School of Medicine.
div.p: This year's graduates from the Khédivial School of Medicine number sixteen, who took doctors' certificates ; nineteen passed to the fourth year's classes'.

div.head: Collapse of House.
div.p: In Cairo, on Sunday, in the Abdin quarter, a house occupied by an Italian family oollap- sed. The tenants, however, warned by the noise, made good their escape.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The meeting of the Legislative Council, which was to have be6n held yesterday, did Dot take place, owing to the absence of a quorum. The meeting was postponed to the 29th inst.

div.head: Transport.
div.p: The hired transport Plassy arrived here on Saturday with 1,304 officers and men on board, under the command of Lieut.-Col. Stanton, en route for Bombay, whence she proceeded yesterday morning.

div.head: Coldstream Guards.
div.p: The 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards, which arrived at Cairo from England last week, will be inspected by Major General Bullook, C. B., General officer commanding, at Abbassieh to-morrow at 8.45 a.m.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The Port Said Vérité reports that the S.S. Isis is leaving to-day for Greenook, where she will be thoroughly overhauled and repaired. In the meantime she will be replaced in the Brindisi mail service by the Peninsular.

div.head: Egypt's Prosperity.
div.p: It is estimated that if Egyptian cotton maintains its present price, and taking the crop at a minimum of six and a quarter million cantars, this season's campaign will absorb over five million pounds sterling more than last year.

div.head: Cook's Cairo Offices.
div.p: The Cairo offices of Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt), Limited, which probably be removed to another site next year, as a road is to made through the site where the offices now Btaud in order to develop the Tewfikieh quarter.

div.head: Creek Benevolence.
div.p: The sum of £2,600 has been subscribed among the Hellenic community of Alexandria in aid of the Greek victims of the Bulgarian atrocities. Emigrants to the number of 160 have arrived at Alexandria and work for 150 of these has been found by the committee in charge of the fund.

div.head: Banquet to Sirdar
div.p: Mahmoud Pasha Suleiman, second secretary of the Legislative Council, is giving a banquet at his residence iu Cairo to day to the Sirdar, Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, and Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha. A number of other English officers ol the Egyptian Army will be among the guests.

div.head: French Cruiser at Port Said.
div.p: The French second class cruiser Alger, bound for Djibouti, arrived at Port Said on Sunday. She will probably pass through the Canal to-day. She is one of their oldest vessels, being laid down in D87, but she was rearmed in 1899, and modernized in other ways.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 13th and 14'h October, 25 vessels, of which 11 were northward and 14 were southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 702,923.23 Of these, 14 were British, 1 German, 1 Russian, 4 American, 2 Dutch, 1 Ottoman, 1 Italian, and 1 French. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 3,738,789.08 and during that time 140 vessels transited the Canal, 60 being northward and 80 southward bound

div.head: Rodah Bridge.
div.p: Considerable progress, it appears, has been made these last few months in the construction of Rodah Bridge. The metallic frame-work is partly built, and it is easy from now to compote when the bridge may be open to traffic, possibly February next. It is over this bridge that a tramway--that between Old Cairo and the Pyramids-will, for the first time in history, cross the Nile. The present Kasr el Nil-Pyramids line will perforce require to be slightly deviated to join this new tramway, but will suffer no loss thereby. The advantage of this Rodah Bridge line is obvions, both to Cairenes and tourists, who flock in such crowds to the famous old monuments.

div.head: NEW MANAGER NOMINATED
div.p: We learn that at a meeting of the Board of the Egyptian State Railways, which was held here onSonday, Lieut. Col. Maeauley Bty.R.E., Director of the Sudan Railways, was nominated General Mauager, subject to the ooLfirmatioD of the appointment by the Council of Ministers.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive returned to Montazah from Mariout yesterday, and will spend the day there. On Friday evening his Highness will hold a reception at Ras el Tin Palace on the occasion of the beginning of the month of Ramadan. The Khedive will leave for Cairo on the 8th proxo., 8nd will be present at the review held on the fallowing day on the anniversary of the accession of H.M. the King.

div.head: TYPHOID ON THE VENUS.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon first class domestic R. Cole, of H.M.S. Venus, was taken to Ras-el-Tin military hospital, suffering from interior fever. He died at 2.45 this morning. The funeral will take place tomorrow morning at the British Cemetery
This is the second case of typhoid fever which has occurred on board the Venus since her arrival of Egyptian waters, the first of which was Captain Eyre, who is in hospital at Port Said.

During the week ending on the 14th inst., 6 cases of bubonique plague were reported for the whole of Egypt, viz, 3 at Alexandria, 2 at Suez, and one in the Minieh district. From January to October 14, 492 cases of plague have been reported, against 264 during the corresponding period in 1905 and 814 in 1904. To-day's bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria, the patient being a boy living in the Qonmrouk quarter. One case was discharged as oared. During the week ending on the 15th Dist., 17 cases of cattle plague were reported, viz., 12 at Bibeh, Beni Soutf Moudirieh, 2 at Fash, 2 at Beni Mazar, and one at Abon Tig.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD.
div.p: Mr. Constantine Meimaraohi, managing director of Walker and Meimaraohi, Limited, Mrs. Meimaraohi, and family are returning to Egypt from Genoa by the Hamburg-American liner Oceana on the 23rd duet., on the first voyage which this magnificently renovated steamer is making between Genoa, Naples, and Egypt. Mr.Mjimarachi will remain managing director of the company, Mr. George Walker general manager, and Mr. Sender Hochstrasser sub manager.

div.head: ST. GEORGE'S CHURCH, JERUSALEM.
div.p: The Bishop in Jerusalem, assisted by Canon Dowling and the Rev. R. Miclanes, lately dedicated the anonymous gift of an Italian marble font, for total immersion, daring evensong. At the west end of St. George's Collegiate Church, Jerusalem, there is on the north side a large baptistery, in the centre of which stands the fine canopied font, the gift of Queen Victoria. The new font, designed by and executed under the direction of Mr. G. E. Jeffery, F.R I.B.A., the architect of the College buildings, is placed directly under the three light window at the east end of the baptistery. The design of the decoration of the baptistery is the same as that of the channel, thus giving equal prominence to the doctrine of the two sacraments ordained by Christ Himself.

A font for the immersion of adults is a necessity where the universal custom of total immersion is common to all Eastern branches of the Church. The Church Missionary Society at Old Cairo have found a font of this description most useful. The only other Anglican font—a circular one -in Turkey is within the baptistery of the Crimean Memorial Church, Constantinople.

The writer renumbers a remark once made by Mgr. Gsrasimos, the late Patriarch of Jerusalem, to Bishop Blyth —' 1 admit the validity of Anglican Order?, but I am not quite satisfied about your baptisms. I hear that some of your clergy do not even pour water on the child, but simply sprinkle. Now it is possible that not one drop of water might tonoh the child." The Bishop's Chaplain at once produced a Book of Common Prayer, and read the rubrio of direction which gives precedence to immersion, but allows the alternative of affusion, and does not recognise sprinkling, upon which the Patriarch observed, "I acknowledge the baptism of the Church of England so administered.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Seti sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 6,084 bales of cotton.

div.head: Mit. BLUNT'S FRENCH TIRADE.
div.p: Mr. Wilfrid Blunt, not content with inflaming fanaticism in Egypt itself, is now attempting to stir up the French to "aid the national Egyptian movement." The courtesy of the "Figaro" has allowed him nearly three columns in which to air his ignorance and his anti-patriotism : but his appeal will certainly be in vain. After nearly a century of evil experience in Egypt, France looks upon that chapter in her history as finally closed, and she iB hardly prepared to endanger British friendship and to re-embark on an old sea of troubles at the bidding of a person whose name is notorious for mischief-making.

After rehearsing a one-sided history of the troobloos times of 1882, in which hep'syed so prominent a part as traitor to his country and inciter of bloodshed, he tarns his attention to the polioy of Lord Cromer. His ideas are so distorted that the publication of them can only proclaim him as a foolish orank, and will go a long way estranging the little sympathy which a few persons may previously have entertained for him. He writes

div.head: Lord Cromer's Policy
div.p: "The policy of Lord Cromer, since 1883, has had no other object than to lead to, by indirect ways, the annexation of Egypt to the British

Empire Financier from his birth, Anglo- Indian bureaucrat by calling, Lord Cromer was in every way the right man to inculcate this régime, and op to last year he did so with remarkable cleverness. My personal relations with him during many years allow me to affirm that he has a frank, loyal, and disinterested nature. In all that concerns his private life and even the conduct of ordinary public affairs, one can trust in him as the safest of men. But in the great affairs of State he is capable of less frank conduct and, as all diplomatists, of lying on occasions.

div.head: The Tabah Incident.
div.p: "At the commencement of the year, the little incident of Tabah, really of secondary importance, placed Lord Cromer in an absolutely false position before the Egyptian public, and he allowed himself to be carried away by self will and violence, which alienated from him the esteem not only of Mussulmans, but of all the sensible men of Egypt. ..lam convinced that if Lord Cromer had had the least idea of what his insistence on this point would cost him in Egypt he would bave taken good care to settle the incident, but a long reign of absolute authority at Cairo did not allow him to'" consider the possibility of sustained opposition, and he yielded to a feeling of amour-propre. From then date all his faults, violence, and false excuses of the last six months.

div.head: A "Schoolboys Error"
div.p: "Among ns one talks of the Tabah incident as a diplomatic victory over the Saltan. Nothing is more absurd! When a great maritime Power each as England, in order to maintain a doubtful claim, mobilises its fleet and launches it against a Power as feeble on the sea as Turkey, it is not an act of diçlomaoy but of violence, an to which can in no way be reckoned as a moral viotory. In faot, Lord Cromer's victory cost him all the influence which he had been able to gain in twenty five years among the Mussulmans of Egypt From this school-boy's error committed by Lord Cromer surges the present phantom of pretended fanaticism on the Nile.

div.head: Fanaticism a Bogey.
div.p: "Europe, however, most not be the dupe of such deceit. Although Lord Cromer lives in Cairo in the midst of flatterers who are imperfectly instructed in the true feelings of the native world, he knows perfectly well that the Mussulmans of the Lower Nile are the least fanatical believers of the entire East, that they have no relation or affiliation with the war like sects of Eastern Africa, and that their patriotic sentiment is as free from religions hatred as that of any European nation All that Lord Cromer says about fanaticism is pure imagination, unworthy of serious discussion, and invented in order to conceal his recent bad conduct of flairs." Whatever may be the opinions of Mr. Blunt on Egyptian questions he renders them worthless by his disregard for facts and his obvions intention to denounce whatever good British diplomacy may effect in Egypt. Let us again remind Mr. Blunt that were he to write as a fair-minded man and honest critic his words would carry some weight.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.
"LA TOSCA."
div.p: Sardou's powerful work is now well known to moBt playgoers, both in opera and drama, and invariably proves a "draw," its diabolical plot and tragic scenes appealing to the taste of many who seek excitement with their pleasure, even in the theatre, a peculiar mingling of sweet and bitter. In Tosca, however, there is very little of the sweet side of nature, and Signor J. Novelli had ample opportunities for portraying the fiendish character of Soarpia, and although he appeared inclined occasionally to remind ns of the vulgar brawl of Nero rather than the refined devilry of the cultured Soarpia, his performance was a very meritorious one. As Floria Tosoa Signa. L. Vidali was very acceptable, end with the exception of being a trifle spasmodic in attaining some of her effects, her performance was an exceedingly good one. In the murder scene she was particularly successful, and was rewarded with a very hearty call. Signor G. Novelli here was also at his best, his death scene leing most realistic. The other characters were all well supported, especially that of Mario Cavaradossi, by Sig. V. Tettoni. The drama was well staged.

div.head: GORDON COLLEGE. KHARTOUM.
WELLCOME RESEARCH LABORATORIES
div.p: The second report of the WelLcome Research Laboratories of the Gordon College has been issued and is full of instructive and encouraging detail, showing, as it does, the steady onward march of civilization. Two years have now passed since the issue of the first report and it may be permitted briefly to recall the primary facts. Than this college, instituted in the place of his death, no better memorial to Gordon could be conceived. Here we have no concern wiffi the work in primary education which that college accomplishes ; merely we may note that one of the native pupils so educated has been appointed as clerk to the laboratories.] It is found that the native is unfit as a subject for scientific education, indeed, it was very soon found that his assistance in the laboratories could not be counted upon; "he cannot be treated beyond the bottle washing stage." This, perhaps, will not appear the most amazing of facts, except to the purblind and pernicious folk who persist in assuming that the lower races of mankind and their life are to be thought of in terms of the psychology of the highest races. The work of these laboratories, then, is not educative in that sense. Their object is to advance scientific knowledge that directly bears upon the welfare and progress of Khartoum and the Anglo-Egyptian Sadan generally.
Dr. Balfour.

The director is a young Scotsman, who belongs to a family that has already supplied many great investigators to the medical profession. Those who were contemporary with him in Edinburgh are well aware of the energy and diligence and might with which he there did whatever his hand found to do. He was a fine student in his undergraduate days, and his thesis, upon an important question of public health concerned with river water, was well worthy of the gold medal which was awarded to it. He was also about as "hot stuff" in the heart of a football "scrum" as ever donned the blue jersey and did battle for the north. Hence, the magnificent success of these laboratories was assured from the moment at which Dr. Balfour's appointment was made. He has been extremely fortunate in his helpers.
Chemical Laboratory.

The report of Dr. William Bsam, who controls the Chemical Laboratory, is a "model of what such a report should be. The present volume contains accounts of exhaustive studies of Nile water, the milk supply of Khartoum, the various grains found in the Sudan, its salt and limestone and gum Arabic. Study has also been made of a number of special varieties of gum. and these must ultimately be of considerable commercial importance. The study of rare native poisons has also been prospected. During the year 1905 Dr. Neave did much valuable work for the laboratories as travelling pathologist and naturalist. This work has mainly dealt with various parasitic diseases, and notably the disease now known as trypanosomiasis, of which sleeping sickness is the last stage. Mr. King, also, has done good work as economic entomologist. The subject with which he is concerned has just been recognised, we believe, in the University of Manchester. It Is of the first practical importance on all the tropical bounds of oar Empire.
Mosquito Brigade.

Bat the most interesting work, of course, is that done by Dr. Balfour himself, or under his direction. Its most important concern, one need hardly say, has been what is now generally known as mosquito work-that is to say, the systematic observation and demotion of the mosquitoes which cause malaria. Complete success has not yet been attained-a study of the difficulties makes us wonder that any success has been attained. Yet already there is a quite unquestionable diminution of malaria in Khartoum ; indeed, it is probable that primary infection is now almost impossible there. For the splendid results being obtained in this direction, all the inhabitants, native and foreign, have to thank Dr. Balfour's Mosquito Brigade. A great deal of other pioneer work has been done in the study of biting and noxious insects other than mosquitoes. With this is included the study of varions parasites or enemies, not merely of man alone, but of many animals and even plants valuable for man. Dr. Balfonr has also been fortunate and Bkilfnl enough to discover a new and interesting parasite, which Professor Laveran, who first found the parasite of malaria, has finally named after the discoverer.

The more ordinary medical work which native patients owe to the laboratories naturally occupies but little space in this report, but at times it has been almost overwhelming in amount. One would like to hear the opinion of the devoted workers in this humane field of the sentiment which the present writer lately heard expressed in London by Mustapha Kamel Pasha : "I deliberately assert that England has done no good in Egypt whatever-except possibly financial good."
The Sleeping Sickness.

Dr. Balfour's gravest concern at the present time will be readily understood by those who know anything of sleeping sickness, the appalling, and at present invariably fatal, character of the disease .the gravity of its incidence wherever it appears-an incidence which the word doorman unite fails to express-and the' fashion in whish, after the first introduction ir.to a now district, such as Uganda, il assumes the characters of a devastating pestilence. The introduction of this disease into the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan would be nothing shorl of an appalling disaster. To this subject Dr Balfonr devotes the largest measure of space in the present report. It must be remembered that the Nile province of Uganda is in close proximity to the Sudan. "This led one to fear," ssys Dr. Balfour, "that, if Glossina palpslis existed on the Upper White Nile in Sudan territory, the disease might spread and play havoc amongst the Baris, Dinkas, and other tribes inhabiting that region." The fly which Dr. Balfour names-or rather the gnat -has been proved by his fellow-countryman, Colonel Bruce, to play in sleeping sickness the same part as the mosquito called Anopheles clavier plays in malaria. Unfortunately, closely allied species of gnats are familiar in the Sudan. The most important work has been done on this subject. Trypanosomiasis has been recognised as extremely prevalent in certain parts of the Sudan, effecting donkeys, horses, and males, and dne, as was long ago observed, to the bites of tsetse flies. The disease has been very carefully studied in cattle and the equine species, both as regards the modes of infection and the symptoms. A good deal of therapeutic research has also been done: notably in what seems to be a very hopeful direction-that is to say, the use of the blood serum of big game whose habitat is in trypanosome-infected areas.
Excellence of Report

It is impossible to speak too highly of the .manner and style of his report. Better I work, more accurate, more painstaking, more scientific, could not have been done in London, or Edinburgh, or Berlin. It is illustrated by a ' very large Dumber of important photographs, a I host ot beautiful plates of various kinds of dangerous insects, of blood cells containing varions parasites, of animals suffering from various kinds of disease, and so forth. If the educational work done at the Gordon Memorial College is in any way comparable to the work which is described here, those who were responsible for its inception may well be satisfied with the fruits of their labour. This report comes at a happily-chosen moment, when certain persons, of the bona Jides of some of whom there is no question whilst others are of the worst type of individuals that can infest any community, are busying themselves in the making of such outrageons assertions as that we have quoted. Here, in palpable form, is a convincing proof - doubtless one of many such-that the role of England in Egypt is a rule of benefice. Surely, when the natives of this ancient land, which played suoh a great, though distant, part in the evolution of the young civilisation that is now engaged in her rejavenesoence - when they begin to realise what the Gordon Memorial College stands for, and to contrast it with the abominations for which Tarkey has been responsible for so long, they may say "The dayspring from on high hath visited ns."
The National Bank of Egypt have opened a branch at Port Sudan under the sub-management of Mr. Evan Dello Strologc, formerly chief accountant of Suakin branch.

The ice factory at Port Sudan belonging to Messrs. Loreozato Bros., which was reported as having been burnt some time ago, has been repaired and started making ice to day. Since the horning of this factory ice has been supplied to Port Sudan from Suez.

The Khédivial Mail S.S. Mahallah left Suakin this mornirg with the following passengers : Mr. Caiger, English secretary to Maoauey Bey, and Mrs. Qaiger, Mr. W.H. Bailey, Inspector of Bridges, S.G.R., who is going to Cairo on leave of absence. The following passengers embarked at Port Sadan for Suez: Kaima- kam Pearson Bey, Director, Sudan Surveys, Done Bey, Assistant Direotor, Sudan Works Dept., and Mr. Crossland, expert in pearls to the Sadan Government.
The hired transport Asiaye, from Bombay, entered the Canal this afternoon bonnd to Southampton.
The division of the American Asiatic Fleet, consisting of four cruisers, sailed from Suez this afternoon for the Far East.

div.head: LOVE POTIONS AT TANTAH.
div.p: A carious ease, illustrative of native customs, came before the Mixed Misdemeanours Court at Alexandria on Saturday last. The Board of Health were the prosecutors and the defendant was a druggist of Tantah, name Mohamed Rayan. This person was known locally as a most skillful concocter of love-potions, and numbered many male and female clients for his mysterious fluid, which was reputed to have a most potent and marvellous feffioacy in stirring the tender passion. Unfortunately, the news of thia druggist's fame reached the ears of the Board of Health authorities in the following manner : A native farmer bought some of the erotic potion and gave it to his wife to drink, after having partaken ol a strong draught himself. The result was that they both suffered exorooiatiDg agonies in the stomach. The victims reported the matter and the Board of Health brought an aotion against the druggist.

In Court the prosecutors produced a bottle of the mysterious aphrodisiao, which they declared contained ingredients of a poisonous character, bnt Mohamed Rayan, who was represented by Mettre Gaston Levy, pleaded that the liqueur was merely compounded of boiled oarrots in the form of herb tea. The Ministère Public demanded that the incriminated love potion should be can fully analysed by an expert and that the druggery of the defendant should be shut up. Judgment will be given at the end of next week.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, will 8f e-id the month of Ramadan at Alexandria, at No 3 Palace, and will only return to Cairo after the Khedive's departure for the Capital

Sir Leslie Randle's appointment to be a colonel commandant of Royal Artillery will be cordially approved. General Randle is a very distinguished officer of tin Royal Regiment, and he has rendered sterling service in various capacities. Sir Leslie Randle is one of the handsomest men in the service, and he possesses the lastly-deserved reputation of being one ot the best-dressed men also. Though he had served iu India and fought well in the Zuln and the Boer campaigns, Sir Leslie Randle did not attain prominence until he entered the Egyptian service, which be joined in 1883, at the same time as Lord Kitchener and Sir Reginald Wingate, and the three comrades fought and made rapid advancement together for sixteen years. The Commander- in Chief of India and General Randle had their first command together twenty-two years ago, when they were dispatched to the Sudan to raise a large force of irregulars, with which they were to relieve Gordon at Khartonm. Sir Leslie Bundle and Sir Francis Wingate are brothers-in law, the Sirdar having married the former's sister. General Bundle is the son of a naval officer, the late Captain J. S. Randle, and he is married himself to the daughter of an Artillery officer, the late Captain H. J. M. Campbell, of Thurmaston Hall, Leicestershire.
Yaconb Pasha ArtiD, Minister of Public Instruction, is returning to Egypt by the Orient steamer which left Marseilles oa the 12th inst.
Ahmed Pasha Fouad, Under Secretary to the Ministry of the Interior, has returned from leave.
The operation to which Fabricins Pasha was recently subjected at Dr. Milton's nursing home has been completely successful, and the Pasha is making rapid strides towards complete recovery.
Sir William Willoocks, K.C.M.G., has returned to Cairo from Cyprus.
Baron Jacques de Menasoe, president of the Jewish community of Alexandria, is arriving at Alexandria by the North German Lloyd S.S. Hohenzollem on the 22nd inst.
M. Prnnières, president of the Mixed Tribunal of 1st Instance in Cairo, is expeoted back from Eubope on the 15'.h proxo.
Mr. Critchley, manager of the Imperial Ottoman Baok at Alexandria, will arrive at Port Said to morrow night from Marseilles.
Mr. HarrisoD, manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, is arriving on the 31st inst by
the P. & O. S.S. Caledonia.
Moberly Bey, inspector in tie Ministry of the Interior, has been granted 12 days' leave, to date from to-day.
Ahmed Khairi Pasha, direotor of the Khassa Wakfs, left for Cairo yesterday morning. •
Mustapha Pasha Kamel was greeted on his arrival at Cairo by Mohamed Bey Ferik and the son of Qassan Bey Madkonr. No other "Nationalists" were at the station to meet him.
Lieutenant T. H. Dimiok, Inspector of Army Sohools, returned to Cairo from Khartonm yesterday, on completion of his inspeotion there.

The funeral of the late Mr. Sawa Baooom, eon of Hanna Bey Bacoom, whose untimely demise at Chambéry we announced recently, will take place at Cairo to morrow. The procession will Btart from Cairo station at 3.30 p.m. and proceed to the Coptio Orthodox Cathedral in Clot Bey-boulevard, where a service will be held.

Captain Watkins, who has been in command of the P. & 0. steamer Isis for several years, is leaving for England to day. We understand that Captain Watkins will shortly be appointed to the command of one of the company's larger liners.

The following visitors are staying at the Bean Rivage Hotel, Ramleh : Dr. and Mrs. H. Heymann, Mr. and Mrs. B. Friend, Mr. Sidney Simpson, Dr. and Mrs. A. Kautzky Bey and family, Mr. and Mrs. Gasset, Mr. A. Smith, Mr. W. Bridson, Miss L. Miles, Mr. Jules Fondor, Mr. and Mrs. L. Horrowi'z, Mr. and Mrs. A. Wellby, Mr. James Watson, Mr. W. Olsen.

On estime k ce propos que si le prix du coton se maintient au niveau actuel et si récolte atteint un minimum de 61/4 million' deoantars, la campagne cotonnière absorbera cette année-ci oinq millions de livres de plus que l'année passée.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Le Caire, 15 Octobre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a éte réduit de 1/8 avant-hier k 4 5/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, samedi passé, le Consolidé a clôturé invarié à 86 5/8, de même que l'Unifiée à 104 1/2 et la National Bank à 26 7/8. La Daïra a gagné 1/8 à 17 et la Delta Light autant k 117/8. L'Agrioole est demeurée inchangée à 9 7/8. A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est restée stationnaire à 778. La Barque d'Athènea a rétrogradé de 1 franc à 144. L'emprunt russe 1906 a passé de 83.70 à 83.80. Ici, contrairement k certaines prédiction pessimistes et conformément k nos prévisions, le marché des valeurs, favorablement impressionné d'ailleurs par la hausse du coton, par la détente de la pénurie monétaire locale et aussi par la baisse du taux d'escompte k Londres, a brillamment commencé la semaine. Lsséacoe a été fort animée, les transactions on' été nombreuses, et nous avons k enregistrer des prix en hausse sur presque toute la ligne de la cote. Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National, très monvementée, a passé de 26 7,8 à 27 1/8 après avoir atteint les environs do 27 5/16. L'Agricole a avanoé k 9 13/16. La Cassa di Sconto a encore progressé k 230 231 l'action anoienne et 227 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier est remonté k 7 1/16, la part de fondateur a été cotée 49. La Banque d'Abyssinie a été mieux tenue k 5 11/16. Le Crédit Foncier a été demandé k 781. La Béhéra s'est inscrite k 37 1/2-3/4. La Nile Land a avanoé à 16 3/8-7/16 ; la part de fondateur a été négooiée k £102. L'action Immobilière a gagné 5 francs k 390 et la part de fondateur 35 francs k 775. L'Enterprise and Development a réaetionné k 12 3/4-13/16 ; par contre, la part de fondateur a haussé k 22 5/8. Les Improvements ont été portés k 6 ponr revenir k 5 15/16 L'Allotment a progressé k 3 7/16 1/2 et la part de fondatear k 131. L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été traitée k 4 3/8 et la partc fondateur k 88-89. La Delta Light a fait 11 7/8. Les Jonissauœs. Eaux du Caire ee sont raffermies k 263-264. Les Automobiles ont rétrogradé k 6 9/16-5/8 ; la part de fondateur a monté k 12. Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les NuDgovich ont été poussés k 18 1/4 pour o'ôturer k 18 1/8, Les Egyptian, Bnr lesquels ilfaut s'attendre, parait il, k apprendre des nou velles importantes, se sont maintenus k 6 ¾. Les Upper Egypt ont é é reoherchés à 5 3/16. La part de fondateur National Hotel a ha ussé k 75. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land, tonjoors fort bien tenus, semblent être à la veille d atteindre, sinon de dépasser, le cours de £4 : ils ont, en attendant, gagné 1/8 k 3 7/8. En excellente tendance, les New Egyptian ont gagpé 1 shelling k 33 sh. 6 Les Estates ont atteint les abords de £2 ; leur part de fon , dateur a béoéfioié de 1/4 è 13 1/8. Les O laisse 'sont rafïermisk 1 1/8 et la Khédivial Mail L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la New Egyptian Go. sera très prochainement tenu an ège social k Londres. A Tordre dn jour : rapport dn conseil d'administration ; présentation des compte pour Texercice arrêté le 30 Juin 1906 ; fixation dn dividende, eto. On Sair que le coapon de l'année pté;édente était de 18 1/2 pour ceut, soit 2 sh. 6 par aotion. On s'attend généralement à ce que le dividende do damier exercice soit très satisfaisant, étant donuéa la bonne marohe constante suivie depuis lors par les affaires de la Société, ainsi que par celles des diverses Compagnies dans l»eque'las la New Egyptian est Intéressée.Tonjonrs est il que, d'après des estimations faite par des personnalités compétentes, la pins value temple des terrains acquis par la Société est énorme et que, dans les condition aotoe'le8, la va'eur intrinsèque du titre pent déjè être calculée au minimum à 50 sb., sans tenir compte du surplus que des opérations récentes on en cours, ainsi que les ventes projetées, pourraient comporter dans nn très proche avenir. Nous nous réservons, d'aillenrs, de donner des renseignements pins précis à ce sujet. Suivant des informations d'Alexandrie, il se conûrme qu'à l'assemblée générale ordinaire du Comptoir Financier et .Commercial, fixée au 27 octobre courant, il sera proposé on dividende annuel de 12 % pour 'es actions et de £2 pour les parts de fondateur. On sait que le oapital primitif de la Compagnie Immobilière d'Egypte a été porté l'année dernière à frs. 6,050,000 et se trouve ainsi représenté maintenant par 21,000 actions de oapital de 250 francs et 6,000 parts de fondateur sans désignation de valeur, dont le nombre ne peut jamais être augmenté. A noter aussi qu'il ne pourra être émis d'actions d'nne catégorie différente de celles orééei par les Statuts. Ponr ce qui est de la répartition statutaire des bénéfices, il est pré'evé : 1° 5 % en faveur du fonds de réserve ; 2° la somme nécessaire pour payer aux actions de oapital un premier dividende de 6 %. Après attribution des tan tièmes et gratifications, le surplus est réparti à raison de 50 % entre toutes les actions de capital et 50 % entre toutes les parts de fondateur. De cette façon, dans les conditions aotuelles, le superdividende de l'action de capital doit toujours atteindre le quart de la rémunération de la part de fondateur. Il res ort du dernier état comparatif des recettes de la Sooiété des Tramways Eleotriques du Caire que les résultats du mois dernier pré sentent un surplus de Fr». 90,900 et ceax de l'année de Frs. 668,000, ce qoi correspond à une augmentation de 25 et 27 %. A la date du 5 Ootobre courant, l'action privilégiée était cotée, à Braxelles, Frs. 6270 et la part de fondateur Frs. 1,034. L'onverture de l'Agence que le Comptoir Na'ional d'Eecompte de Paris a établie au Caire a eu lieu ce matin. Cette agence, qui fonctionnera dans las mé mes conditions qoe le Comptoir lui-même, a pour directeur M. William Llewellyn et pour sous directeur M. Georges J. Baissez.

div.head: THE ENTENTE CORDIALE. LORD MAYOR'S PARIS VISIT

div.p: The Lord Mayor and Aldermen drove in a State procession through the principal streets of the city to the Hotel de-Ville. They were rapturously welcomed by the densely massed crowds. The weather was magnificent. The Parisians were delighted with the brilliance of the Civico cortège.(Reuters)
The Lord Mayor of London was received at the Hotel de Ville and at the Élysée. The Entente Cordiale was toasted. (Haxas)
A colliery explosion has taken place at Wingate (Durham). 12 dead bodies have been recovered. It is stated that 200 men are entombed.
Later.

Up to the present 30 bodies have been recovered. The work is proceeding. The utmost heroism has been exhibited. Several Labour Members of Parliament assisted at the resene work. Great crowds are gathered round thepit-bead, where the most distressing scenes are witnessed. (Reuter)
Trouble is brewing between France andMorocco. The latter is creating all sorts of difficulties with regard to trade between Tafilet and Southern Algeria. (Reuter)

div.head:
GREEK AND BÜLGAR.
MURDERS IN MACEDONIA.

div.p: Owing to the frequency of murders of Bulgarians by Greeks in the districts of Drama and Kavalla, which are within British gendarmerie supervision, the Grand Vizier has made strong complaints to the Hellenio Minister of the presence of Greek bands in Macedonia, also of the conduct of the Greek Consular officers and the Metropolitan of Drama, demanding the latter's recall. (Reuter)

The "Standard" learn* that the Admiralty intends to place four battleships of the Majestic class from the Channel Fleet and two of the Atlantic Fleet, and two t-f the Formid able class from the Mediterranean Fleet reserve, with nucleus ore's, and to place the whole the of vessels of the Royal Sovereign class in reserve without crews. The men thus set free will go towards increasing the anciens crews and torpedo flortillas. (R.)

The Hankow carried matting and raw silk. She was ablaze fore and aft within five minutes. It was impossible to rescue the shrieking. Chinese steerage passengers, many of whom jumped out and were drowned. The cause of the fire is suspected to be incendiarism in connection with the boycott of the British river boats. (Reuter)
Nine persons were killed and seventeen injured in a train wreck near Chantres. (R.)
A serions railway accident is reported from Epernon, on the Western line. Ten persons were killed and thirty injured, several dangerously. (Havas)

Longchamps presented the appearance of a regular pandemonium. The mob fought wildly amongst one another for booty. Some invaded the bars and became intoxicated, some tore about, madly brandishing stolen bank-notes, of which they were soon robbed by others. Hardly aoy building on the coarse escaped damage or destruction. Sixty arrests have been made. (Reuter)

Prince Alexander of Hohenlohe, who is responsible for the publication of his father's memoirs, had a long interview with Princevon Bulow and afterwards resigned his office of the sub-governorship of Alsace. (Reuter)

Bertha Krupp, the richest German heiress has been married to Herr von Bohlen-Halbach,of the diplomatic service, who becomes the bead of the Krupp firm. The Emperor William was present at the ceremony. (Reuter)

div.head: EGYPTIAN IMPORTS FROM BRITAIN.
div.p: MANCHESTER GOODS.

The British Chamber of Commerce remarks in the "Monthly Journal" that business in Manchester piece goods was quiet during September, though not less so than was expected. The firmness of the market in Manchester, together with the distant delivery still required by manufacturers, tended to keep prices up at his end. In fact, in some cases, higher prices have been asked and paid than those which ruled last month, and it appears likely that we shall see still higher figures here during the next few months. This is very much to be desired, as the prices which have ruled through-out the Summer have in many articles been remunerative. Bayers, in many instances, are in treaty for forward business, but sellers do not seem inclined to dose with them unless at their own quotations. Everything seems to point to a busy season at better prices than those which have obtained so far this year. In hemp and tow yarns there has not been much doing, but buyers fully realise that prices are unlikely to recede for some time to come, and many transactions have been pot through for delivery during the first few months of next year. Lancashire cotton yams have been in rather better demand daring the month and, in this article also, prices have been better.Altogether trade seems to be in a healthier condition than it has been for some little time and hopes are generally entertained that the next three months will improve the general result for the year.

div.head: ÜM RUS GOLD MINES OF EGYPT
div.p: The statutory meeting of the shareholders of the Um Ras Gold Mines of Egypt (Limited), at 6, Queen-street-place, London, last week was presided over by the chairman, Mr. J. Harvey, who said the company was formed on July 5th Up to the present 135,585 shares had been applied for, applications were still coming in, and the directors hoped that several more could be taken up. In July 529 tons of ore were mined, and yielded 353 ounces of gold, valued at £1,259 6s. 9d. In August €92 tons of ore yielded §35 ounces of gold of the estimated vaine of £2,224. In addition to this, there was a later yield of 280 ounces. The Board and managers came to the conclusion that the best thing to do would be to suspend milling operations temporarily and develop the property more than had hitherto been done, and also augment the reserve of ore, so that the monthly output could be increased to the foil capacity of the mill. Mr. B. J. Haythornthwaite, a shareholder, said that the number of shares unissued was 44,415, What did the directors propose to do with regard to these shares? One thousand six hundred and eighty-six shares had been applied for and not allotted. Why was that, and who had applied for them? The Chairman said the shares were originally offered to all the shareholders, and if anyone liked to apply for any more they would no doubt receive some. There was no option. The list was still open, and the directors had only that day allotted a farther number of shares. All that had been applied for to date had been allotted, The directors did not intend to put the shares on the market, because it would not be right to the shareholders to do so. The money would all be paid up—it was quite good. Shareholders must be allowed some consideration. Probably they had been away and had not had time to pay the money. He believed a mine never had been opened up so advantageously as this one. Roughly, £1,200 to £1,500 a month were the working expenses. Mr. Haythornthwaite t Gold has been sold at more than that, and if so why are shareholders being called on to find more money? The Chairman : This is only a statutory meeting, and I am not prepared to answer all these questions. (Hear, hear). Mr. Haythornthwaite ; How many clerks, managers, and others are employed in the office staff. The Chairman: No more than are necessary. Mr. Haythornthwaite: Well, I have been informed that the mine is mismanaged. (Laughter and "Name !"). I am told the company have wasted their resources. (Renewed laughter.) Mr. Haythornthwaite then repeated several of his questions. A Shareholder said time was being wasted by a man who evidently knew nothing about mines or companies. (Hear, hear.) The Chairman said that if the questions were brought forward at a general meeting they would no doubt be answered.The motion was then carried without opposition. Mr. J. Taylor, the manager, said that since the general meeting 1,528ft. of development work had been accomplished.

div.head: LIFE IN THE TROPICS.
div.p: Sir Francis Lovell, in the absence of the Duke of Marlborough, presided last week at the opening of the winter session of the London School of Tropical Medicine. Colonel Kenneth MacLeod, hon. physician to the King, delivered the inaugural address. He said the school was able to pay its way, but it needed extension to carry ont its two fold object of education and research. Only £40,000 of the £100,000 sought three years ago had been subscribed, and surely the wealthiest and busiest port in the world might be reasonably expected to contribute handsomely to the support of such an institution ! He saw no reason why health should be worse and life shorter in tropical than in northern latitudes, when the conditions which affected vitality and longevity were property understood, and made the subjeot of proper control. Sanitary education should be made universal and compulsory.

div.head: ARMY CHANGES IN INDIA-
div.p: LORD KITCHENER'S NEW PLANS-

Commencing this month, some important changes will be inaugurated in the staff of the Army in India. A very careful survey has been made by Lord Kitohener, with the result that there will be an alteration in the commands in the future, and the power and responsibility will be more centralised. It has been found, the "Standard" states, that there are too many commands and commanders, and that this evil is widespread from the chief posts to the minor ones. It has been the fashion for every civil district to have troops in order to dignify the station headquarters, and quite apart from military requirements. The redistribution under this head has already commenced.The important point of the moment lies in the higher commands, Buck as the Northern at Rawal Pindi, the Western at Poona, and the Eastern at Naini Tal. These commande are considered to embrace too much territory and to be unwieldly for the purposes of administration. A general holding one of these big appointments is very much in the hands of his Subordinate generals, and it is considered that there should be nine commanders with full powers instead of three. These nine generals would be the commanders of the divisions which were recently created by Lord Kitchener, and which, therefore, already exist.The three supreme generals may be removed and their powers and responsibility divided among the divisional chiefs.
If this plan is carried out the new generals-in-chief would be as follows ;—
1st Division, Peshawar.
2nd Division, Rawal Pindi.
3rd Division, Lahore.
4th Division, Quetta.
5th Division, Mhow.
6th Division, Poona.
7th Division, Meerut.'
8th Division, Lucknow.
9th Division, Socandorabad.

There is also a 10th Division in Burma,which is already a selfcontained command.The lieutenant-generals commanding the big areas are Sir Bindon Blood, one of the best officers in the service, who retires October 18 from the Northern Command ; Sir Arohibald Hunter, Western Command ; and Sir Alfred Gaselee, Eastern Command. The former has been temporarily succeeded by Sir Edmund Bam Jr.

A complete revision is to be made in military education and also in training. An officer, who will be practically an inspector genera), will visit all the stations and keep the methods of instruction up to date and on common lines. The General Staff scheme for India is ready, but its application is delayed owing to the home plans not being sufficiently forward.

The general idea is to make training, preparation, and organization similar in character at home and in India, so that in war time there will be no confusion when the two branches blend. In this way the new home divisions will be of three brigades each, and it is probable that the divisional commanders at home may be given the responsibilities now held by generals of the commands. Aldershot and Ireland will be two division stations, and the eastern and southern commands will have one each.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
